subtopic: Trade Union Act 1926 and Communist Influence

flashcards.back: The Trade Union Act of 1926 legalised trade unions, granting them recognition and regulating their activities. It required at least seven members for registration, provided immunity from civil and criminal liability for legitimate actions, and allowed unions to own property. However, the Act restricted unions from using funds for political purposes, limiting their activities to economic grievances only

Led by the Girni Kamgar Union (GKU), mobilized 1.5 lakh mill workers and lasted five months. This strike marked a decisive shift from scattered labour protests to a structured industrial movement, establishing early working-class solidarity in India

flashcards.front: Communist influence on trade union movement (Late 1920s)?
flashcards.back: The rise of communism in the late 1920s significantly influenced the Indian trade union movement, giving it a more militant and revolutionary tone. The Girni Kamgar Union led a six-month strike at the Bombay Textile Mills in 1928, marking a period of intense industrial unrest driven by communist ideologies

flashcards.front: Communist leaders in trade union movement?
flashcards.back: Key figures such as Sohan Singh Joshi, P.C. Joshi, Muzaffar Ahmed, and S.A. Dange played a central role in the communist-influenced trade union movement

flashcards.front: 4th Congress of Communist International and AITUC?
flashcards.back: The 4th Congress of the Communist International urged the AITUC to not just demand fair wages, but to focus on overthrowing capitalism and imperialism. AITUC later affiliated with the Pan-Pacific Secretariat and the Third International in Moscow
In response to the radical shift, moderates led by N.M. Joshi formed the All India Trade Union Federation (AITUF) in 1931, after withdrawing from the AITUC

flashcards.front: Trade Disputes Act (TDA), 1929 - Courts and Boards?
flashcards.back: Compulsory Appointment of Courts of Inquiry and Consultation Boards to settle industrial disputes
Strikes in public utility services (like railways, posts, water, and electricity) were made illegal unless individual workers gave a one-month notice
The Act forbade coercive or purely political trade union activities, including sympathetic strikes [UPSC 2017]

This ordinance, introduced in the Legislative Assembly in 1928 and enacted in 1929, was aimed at regulating and limiting labour movements and public safety concerns. It provided for a system of tribunals and a ban on strikes [UPSC 2017]
